title: Windows Build Errors

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Issues or features that are good starter tasks that we would love the communities help with.

I'm doing a fresh build. Did npm install on windows 10 and then npm run dev, but i'm getting this error. Did I not install one of the requirements?

Hey @sulkhanp,

The bulk of the team is on Unix-based operating systems, so sometimes Windows support falls by the wayside. I've got a Windows machine at home that I'll try to run through and see if I get the same issues. FWIW the first error message you posted usually has more logging information in your terminal. It just shows that whenever `index.html` cannot be output. Until I can get a better look though, my suggestions would be:

* Make sure you are on a version of node >= 8.0.0
* Try deleting `node_modules` and reinstalling, in case there's any weird caching going on

Hello @wbobeirne,
Thanks for responding quickly. I have node v8.7.0. I tried reinstalling node_modules, but it didn't change anything.

Alright, I found some time to run through this, and boy is it a pain in the ass. Took a while to even get the modules to install (Couldn't find python, couldn't find node-gyp, etc. etc.)

I figured out a _hilarious_ reason for the main issue. We use a component called `Aux` to reduce unnecessary nesting, however `AUX` is a reserved filename in the windows system. So cloning the repo omits the file `common/components/ui/Aux.tsx`, which blows up the build. I'll put up a PR that renames this. (EDIT: Pr is #771)

After that, I was still left with the scss errors. We use `node-sass`, and they [have a guide on windows installation](https://github.com/sass/node-sass/blob/master/TROUBLESHOOTING.md#windows). That guide personally didn't work for me, but someone suggested I run `npm rebuild node-sass` and that seemed to fix some of them up.

However, after _all_ of that, I still ended up with some errors that I'm still trying to sort out. Windows support is definitely something I'd like to work out long term, but in the short term early stages of this project, I don't feel I can spend too much time looking into it. Running a VM or the windows ubuntu bash prompt will chop this Gordian knot much faster than I can untangle it.
It goes without saying though, if you can find a way to get the build working well in Windows, I'd be happy to test and review any changes that need to happen!

I managed to get it to build and run via `npm run dev` on Windows by doing the following:

1. Removing the line `exclude: /node_modules(?!\/font-awesome)/` from `webpack.dev.js`.
(which makes font-awesome's .scss files load using `sass-loader`)
2. Removing the same line from `webpack.base.js`
(which makes font-awesome's .svg files load using `file-loader`)

I don't have access to Unix machine right now, so I can't check if it breaks anything in non-Windows environments :(
Also I have no idea why `font-awesome` directory was excluded from those loaders in the first place.

@sulkhanp Took me some time but I believe i was able to debug your issue. Try these steps:

1. Remove `exclude: /node_modules(?!\/font-awesome)/,` from `makeConfig.js` on lines `107`, `127`, and `162`.
2. In your terminal run `npm rebuild node-sass`.
3. Run `npm run dev`

That should fix your issue.

@dternyak @sulkhanp ok to pay out?

While that instruction works, I think we'll need a code change before we call this solved. Before we just remove those lines though, I'd like to find out why we were excluding font-awesome in the first place. Git blame has me committing those, but that was just from a refactor. I can't actually remember why they were excluded in the first place.
@wbobeirne mind sending me the commit of when you added the code to exclude `font-awesome`? So i can get a bit of context.

@wbobeirne @sulkhanp @dternyak So font awesome pulls in files with the following extensions `.svg`, `.eot`, `.scss`, `.woff`, and `.ttf`. If you exclude those and there is not proper way to handle those files then errors will be thrown.
@lazaridiscom thanks for checking on this. I've been meaning to check this one. I didn't get the bounty yet :/

Hi Kenneth,

Thanks for your comment. We're waiting on the code changes (in the form of
a PR) so that the build won't fail on Windows in the future. In general,
all bountied issues should have an associated PR, that once merged will
release the bounty.
